access.description: The registered URL is a direct link to a PDF file hosted on agilon health's WordPress site. No redirects, no page navigation, no JavaScript rendering required. The PDF downloaded immediately with a standard curl request. Served via Cloudflare CDN with no anti-bot protection beyond standard Cloudflare cookies.

products.name: Minerva

product_context.description: Minerva is a FHIR-based Healthcare Data Platform-as-a-Service, originally built by mphrX (founded 2011) and acquired by agilon health in February 2023 for $45M. It is NOT a traditional EHR — it is an interoperability and data aggregation middleware platform. Minerva aggregates clinical data from disparate EHR systems (Epic, Cerner, athenahealth, etc.) into a unified, vendor-neutral FHIR repository, creating a longitudinal patient record. It provides SMART on FHIR and Bulk FHIR APIs for programmatic access. The broader Minerva platform includes a white-labeled 'Digital Front Door' patient portal with appointment booking and notifications, surgery coordination with OR scheduling, virtual care/telehealth, and care pathway management. agilon health itself is a value-based care enablement company (NYSE: AGL) that partners with independent primary care physician groups serving Medicare populations. agilon's physician partners use their own EHRs for clinical documentation; Minerva serves as a data aggregation layer. The certified module covers Minerva's ability to store health data in FHIR format and expose it through standardized APIs and bulk export. It does not certify clinical workflow capabilities. Minerva integrates with billing gateways but is not a native billing system. It does not generate clinical documentation — it aggregates it from source systems.

export_approach.description: Minerva exports EHI as FHIR R4 NDJSON files via two mechanisms: (1) Single patient export from the Minerva portal UI — a Clinical Admin selects a patient, clicks 'Export EHI,' and receives a ZIP file containing one NDJSON file per FHIR resource type plus a readme.txt; (2) Bulk export via FHIR Bulk Data Access API (Patient/$export) using SMART Backend Services Authorization (client credentials with signed JWT). The bulk API is async — client polls a Content-Location URL for status, then downloads NDJSON files when complete. Files are split at 10,000 records per file. This is a pure FHIR resource export, not a native database dump. The export is limited to 21 FHIR resource types. Because Minerva is a data aggregation platform rather than a source EHR, the exported data is whatever was ingested from upstream source systems and mapped to these FHIR resources. This approach adds little beyond what the FHIR API itself provides — it is essentially the same data in bulk file form rather than API access.

documentation_quality.description: The 12-page PDF describes the export process (how to trigger it via UI or API, authentication steps, API endpoints, error codes) but provides essentially zero detail about the data content. There are no field definitions, no data dictionaries, no schema descriptions, no sample data. The only content detail is a flat list of 21 FHIR resource type names and a link to the generic HL7 NDJSON specification. Users must refer to the FHIR R4 specification for format details. The document is version 1.0, copyright 2021 by mphrX (pre-acquisition), and has not been updated in nearly 5 years. It still carries mphrX branding exclusively with no mention of agilon health.
documentation_quality.documentation_last_updated: 2021 (copyright date; last-modified header shows 2025-01-31 but content unchanged)

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: The export covers 21 standard FHIR R4 clinical resource types, providing reasonable clinical data coverage but entirely missing billing, insurance, scheduling, and messaging categories. Given that Minerva is a data aggregation platform (not a source EHR), the export is inherently limited to what was ingested from upstream systems and mapped to FHIR resources. The broader Minerva platform includes patient portal capabilities (appointment booking, notifications), surgery coordination, and billing gateway integrations, but data from these features is absent from the export. The export essentially repackages FHIR API data as NDJSON files, adding little beyond what the standardized FHIR API (g)(10) already provides. For a platform that sits atop source EHRs, the more critical EHI exports would come from those source systems, not from this aggregation layer.

clinical.evidence: 21 FHIR resource types include core clinical resources: AllergyIntolerance, Condition (diagnoses), Medication, MedicationRequest, Immunization, Observation (vitals, labs), Procedure, DiagnosticReport, ClinicalImpression, CarePlan, CareTeam, Goal, Device. Coverage of standard clinical categories is reasonable within FHIR R4 constraints, though limited to data that was ingested from source EHRs and successfully mapped.

secure_messages.evidence: No messaging-related FHIR resources (Communication, CommunicationRequest) in the supported resource list. Minerva's Digital Front Door patient portal includes notification and engagement capabilities, suggesting communication data may exist in the system but is not exported.

billing_financial.evidence: No billing-related FHIR resources (Claim, ClaimResponse, ExplanationOfBenefit, ChargeItem, Invoice, Account) included. Minerva integrates with billing gateways but is not a native billing system. However, if financial data transits the platform, it is not exported.

insurance_coverage.evidence: No insurance-related FHIR resources (Coverage, InsurancePlan, ExplanationOfBenefit) included. Given agilon health's Medicare Advantage/value-based care focus, insurance and coverage data likely flows through the broader platform but is absent from the Minerva export.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: No scheduling-related FHIR resources (Appointment, Schedule, Slot) included. This is a notable gap given that Minerva's Digital Front Door portal includes appointment booking and the surgery coordination module manages OR scheduling.

documents_images.evidence: DocumentReference is a supported resource type, capturing references to clinical documents aggregated from source systems. However, it is unclear whether actual document content (binary attachments, images, scanned documents) is included in the export or only metadata references.

audit_trails.evidence: Provenance is included as a supported resource type. FHIR Provenance records track who created or modified resources and when, providing basic data lineage. However, this is not a comprehensive access audit log — it does not capture who viewed records, only data provenance metadata.

issues: FHIR-only export with significant category gaps: no billing, insurance, scheduling, or messaging resources despite the platform having capabilities in scheduling and patient engagement.

Data aggregation platform, not source system: the export only includes data that was ingested from upstream EHRs and mapped to FHIR resources. Source EHRs hold the authoritative, complete records. This raises questions about what b(10) requires for an aggregation platform.
Documentation is severely outdated: version 1.0, copyright 2021, with mphrX branding only. No updates in nearly 5 years despite the 2023 acquisition by agilon health.
No data dictionary or field-level documentation: the PDF describes only the export process, not the data content. Users are directed to the generic FHIR specification.
Bulk export API access token requires emailing techsvc@mphrx.com — a pre-acquisition email address of uncertain current status. Not self-service.
Export files auto-deleted after 48 hours, which could be problematic for large exports.
The export adds little beyond the FHIR API (g)(10) — same data, same format, just delivered as bulk files rather than API calls.
products.summary: Minerva is a FHIR-based data aggregation platform (not a source EHR) that exports 21 FHIR R4 resource types as NDJSON files. The export covers standard clinical data but entirely omits billing, insurance, scheduling, and messaging categories. The documentation is a 12-page process guide with no data dictionary, outdated by nearly 5 years, and still carrying pre-acquisition mphrX branding.

downloaded_files.description: EHI Export documentation PDF (12 pages). Describes the export process for single-patient UI export and bulk FHIR API export. Lists 21 supported FHIR resource types. No data dictionary or field-level detail. Version 1.0, copyright 2021 by mphrX.

summary: agilon health's Minerva product (originally built by mphrX, acquired 2023) is a FHIR-based data aggregation platform — not a source EHR. Its EHI export provides 21 FHIR R4 resource types as NDJSON files, covering standard clinical data but omitting billing, insurance, scheduling, and messaging. The 12-page documentation is purely procedural (how to trigger the export) with no data dictionary. It is outdated (v1.0, copyright 2021, mphrX-branded) and has not been updated post-acquisition. The export essentially repackages the same data available through the FHIR API, adding minimal value beyond what (g)(10) already provides.
notes: The mphrX/agilon health relationship is important context: mphrX was an independent health IT company that built Minerva and obtained ONC certification in 2021. agilon health (a value-based care services company, not traditionally a health IT vendor) acquired mphrX in February 2023 for $45M to integrate Minerva's data aggregation capabilities into its enterprise platform. The EHI documentation still reflects the pre-acquisition state entirely. The fundamental nature of Minerva as an aggregation layer (not a source system) makes the b(10) completeness question somewhat different from a traditional EHR — the 'product' stores aggregated FHIR data from other systems, so its export is inherently a derivative of upstream source data rather than original clinical records.
